Photo.Title: Mighty Deed
Photo.Description: Charter establishing Holy Trinity Priory (known as the Christchurch) in Aldgate in London as a religious house. The priory was founded by Queen Matilda, the wife of King Henry I and her personal confessor became the first Prior. The seal is the great seal of King Henry I.

Photo.Title: Smiting the Dragon of Sin
Photo.Description: The Archangel Michael spears a beast with "the strength of God" in a page from the Black Book of the Exchequer.

Photo.Title: Medieval Landholder with beard
Photo.Description: Portrait of 13th century landowner in one of the Home Counties (Kent or Sussex). Illumination with gilt from Abbreviatio (abridgement) of Domesday Book.

Photo.Title: Medieval Landholder
Photo.Description: Portrait of 13th century landowner in one of the Home Counties (Kent or Sussex). Illumination with gilt from Abbreviatio (abridgement) of Domesday Book.

Photo.Title: Medieval Multiculturalism?
Photo.Description: Detail of a page from a 13th century Abbreviatio (abridgement) of Domesday Book. A black man wearing brightly coloured stockings is suspended from the initial letter 'I'.

Photo.Title: Medieval Miracles
Photo.Description: Page from a 13th century Abbreviatio (abridgement) of Domesday Book. Above King Edward the Confessor and Earl Leofric of Mercia see the face of Christ appear in the Eucharist wafer and below the return of a ring given to a beggar who was John the Baptist in disguise.

Photo.Title: Turbulent Priest
Photo.Description: Pen portrait of a man in clerical dress (probably Thomas Beckett) being hit on the head with a sword, from a book of treasury receipts.

Photo.Title: Kingly Gesture
Photo.Description: A stubbled King Edward I points to some lettering on a page from a memoranda roll, held in the Exchequer. The document comes from the records of the Lord Treasurer's Remembrancer.

Photo.Title: All dressed up
Photo.Description: Pen portrait from 'Bishop Stapelton's Calendar' from the reign of Edward II

Photo.Title: Treaty of Calais Chest
Photo.Description: Chest made to hold the Treaty of Calais, signed between Edward III of England and John II of France. Edward agreed to give up his claim to the throne of France in exchange for the territory of Aquitaine.

Photo.Title: Charge!
Photo.Description:
Illustration from the Liber Memoranda Camerarii, a book cataloguing the delivery of deeds of title, jewels, and other items received into or delivered out of the Treasury of the Exchequer.
The illustration is based on the images drawn or painted on the chests and boxes in which the objects and documents were placed. Matching the two would allow items listed to be found easily.

Photo.Title: Medieval Warrior
Photo.Description: Pen portrait of a warrior from a book of treasury receipts

Photo.Title: Illumination of Henry IV
Photo.Description: Illuminated initial letter showing Henry IV from the records of the Duchy of Lancaster. Before his usurpation of Richard II in 1399, Henry was Duke of Lancaster.

Photo.Title: Virgin and Child
Photo.Description: Portion of illuminated manuscript page from documents relating to Furness Abbey in Cumbria.

Photo.Title: Furness Abbey Manuscript
Photo.Description: Detail of illuminated manuscript page from documents relating to Furness Abbey in Cumbria.

Photo.Title: The King in Parliament
Photo.Description: Illuminated initial from a 15th century book of statutes showing the King (Edward IV?) in Parliament seated under a canopy with the Lords Spiritual (left) and the Lords Temporal (right).

Photo.Title: Lancastrian Rose
Photo.Description: Coram Rege Roll of Henry VII. The roll records court proceedings that were supposed to be carried out before the king in person (coram rege), although that was rarely true. The rolls often include a portrait of the monarch as if to suggest this presence but here the red rose of Lancaster stands in for King Henry VII.

Photo.Title: Royal Charity Performance
Photo.Description: Detail from document connected with the foundation of Henry VII's chantry and almshouses at Westminster. The King sits in the Star Chamber and receives the Archbishop of Canterbury William Warham, Richard Fox, the Bishop of Westminster and clerics associated with Westminster Abbey and St. Paul's Cathedral as well as the Mayor of London.

Photo.Title: Give peace a chance
Photo.Description: A treaty of perpetual peace between England and France signed between Francis I and Henry VIII. This is the French ratification of the treaty, signed at Amiens. The strands at the bottom were attached to Francis' unusual gold seal. The peace lasted fewer than twenty years. The portrait in the top left is of Francis himself.

Photo.Title: Abbey Seal
Photo.Description: Seal of St. Benet's Abbey, Hulme in Norfolk attached to acknowledgement of the Royal Supremacy, where the English Church was made to accept Henry VIII as head instead of the Pope.

Photo.Title: Valor Ecclesiasticus
Photo.Description: Illuminated title page of Valor Ecclesiasticus, the survey of the lands and wealth of England's monasteries prepared for Henry VIII.

Photo.Title: CO 1069-7-18
Photo.Description:
View of the Mountain of Devra Damo.
Location: Adowa, Massowah, Abyssinia

Photo.Title: Yours as long as life endures, Katheryn
Photo.Description:
This is the only surviving letter written by Katherine Howard, Henry VIII's fifth wife.
The ill advised letter to Thomas Culpepper, a gentleman of the Privy Chamber and other reports of her infidelity led to Katherine's execution in 1542, less than six months after her marriage to Henry.

Photo.Title: Martin Luther
Photo.Description: Coloured woodcut portrait of Martin Luther with verses in German.

Photo.Title: Knaresborough Castle
Photo.Description: Plan of Knaresborough Castle in Yorkshire.

Photo.Title: Grant of Arms
Photo.Description: Signed grant from the Clarenceux King of Arms Robert Cooke to Henry Draper of Colnbrook giving him the right to use the heraldry shown.

Photo.Title: Gloriana
Photo.Description: Coram Rege Roll of Elizabeth I. The roll records court proceedings that were supposed to be carried out before the king in person (coram rege), although that was rarely true. The rolls often include a portrait of the monarch as if to suggest this presence.

Photo.Title: Great Seal of Elizabeth I
Photo.Description: Obverse (front) of the Great Seal of Elizabeth I. The Great Seal was used by the Chancery, the Tudor Civil service, to show that the document attached was ordered in the Queen’s name. The pattern (or matrix) for this seal was produced by the artist Nicholas Hilliard in 1586.

Photo.Title: The Golden Speech
Photo.Description: Official printed copy of Elizabeth I's "Golden Speech" delivered in the Presence Chamber at Whitehall Palace to 141 MPs. Attacked for granting lucrative trading rights to favoured courtiers the Queen responded with a speech which totally disarmed the distrustful audience.

Photo.Title: Recipe for six mince pies of 'an indifferent bigness'
Photo.Description:
This recipe for “Six Minst Pyes" is bound amongst the Conway Papers, part of the State Papers of Charles I, created by Edward Conway, Charles’ Secretary of State.
Although at first it may seem strange for there to be a mince pie recipe tucked in amongst the more usual documents of the Secretary of State and the Privy Council, it is worth remembering that many of the Secretaries treated the State Papers as their own filing system. It is therefore not unusual to find items such as poems, drawings or recipes amongst them.

Photo.Title: Read all about it
Photo.Description: Front page of London's Intelligencer weekly newspaper during the height of the English Civil War.

Photo.Title: The soldiers are revolting
Photo.Description: Leveller sympathisers within the New Model Army staged a mutiny in May 1649 quickly put down by Cromwell. This pamphlet describes events, siding with the army commanders against the mutineers.

Photo.Title: London defies ban on Christmas
Photo.Description:
This note from Oliver Cromwell from the State Papers refers to a report that people in the City of London and in Westminster have been flouting his ban on celebrating Christmas.
When Cromwell and his Puritan forces took over England, they banned Christmas in an effort to rid the country of decadence. Soldiers were ordered to go round the streets and take food being cooked for a Christmas celebration, by force if necessary. Traditional Christmas decorations like holly were also banned. This move was unpopular with the people of England, many of whom resisted it.

Photo.Title: CO 1069-34-3
Photo.Description:
View in Anamabu, showing ruins of Slave Traders' House (built about 1690) Anamabu Church in distance (Wesbyan).
Location: Anamabu

Photo.Title: King William III
Photo.Description: Portrait of King William III on a Treasury document appointing Lord Commissioners of the Treasury.

Photo.Title: Get back in the knife drawer
Photo.Description: Three knives with holder and cover. Objects are sometimes unexpectedly found amongst bundles of papers. The origin of these items is unknown.

Photo.Title: Queen Anne
Photo.Description: Description: Portrait of Queen Anne on a document appointing Lord Commissioners of the Treasury.

Photo.Title: Dick Turpin: Horsethief
Photo.Description: Tied bundle of court records including the indictment of Richard ‘Dick’ Turpin, for stealing a mare worth three pounds from Thomas Creasy, at Welton, Yorkshire.

Photo.Title: George Island, Sierra Leone
Photo.Description: "A Plan of the Fort and Factory on George Island in the River Sierraleon or Sierra Leona, Lat. 8° 10' North. Surveyed in December, 1748, by Jos. Wade. MS. 20 feet to 1 inch. Author, Publisher, &c.: Wade, Jos."

Photo.Title: CO 1069-34-61
Photo.Description:
Main street, Elmina. (showing old Dutch house built about 1750).
Location: Elmina

Photo.Title: Portrait of an unknown man
Photo.Description: One half of a portrait miniature from the effects of Mary Smith, an inmate of Christ's Hospital in London.

Photo.Title: Easter Island
Photo.Description: Map and sketches of Easter Island from J Gilbert's log of the voyage of HMS Resolution through the Pacific from 1772-5.

Photo.Title: Monumental
Photo.Description: Design of planned memorial to General Dundas in St. Paul's Cathedral by sculptor John Bacon.

Photo.Title: Gladstone's Red Box
Photo.Description: In the past many government departments passed documents to ministers in red boxes. However the Chancellor of the Exchequer's red 'Budget Box' is the most well known. This is William Ewart Gladstone's budget box. In addition to four terms as Prime Minister, Gladstone served as Chancellor four times between 1852 and 1882.

Photo.Title: CO 1069-7-4
Photo.Description:
Pass of Taranta.
Location: Abyssinia

Photo.Title: Nelson's Last Voyage
Photo.Description: Print of the royal barge carrying Admiral Nelson's body along the River Thames from Greenwich to Whitehall.

Photo.Title: Seal of Nathaniel Wells
Photo.Description: Wax seal of Nathaniel Wells, a Monmouthshire Justice of the Peace.

Photo.Title: CO 1069-90-35
Photo.Description: Robari

Photo.Title: God always saves endavour
Photo.Description:
Sketch of a flag taken from rebels against slavery in Barbados, after the uprising known as Bussa's Rebellion.
The flag appears to stress the rebels' loyalty to Britain and to the Crown while conveying their earnest desire for liberty. British forces on Barbados suppressed the revolt and hundreds of the rebels were killed.
<a target="_new" href="http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/education/lessons/lesson52.htm" rel="nofollow">Learn more about Bussa's Rebellion on The National Archives website.

Photo.Title: Jane Austen's Will
Photo.Description: Last will and testament of the writer Jane Austen, written three months before her death. With the exception of a few small legacies, Jane left "everything" to her sister Cassandra.

Photo.Title: CO 1069-214-30
Photo.Description:
The Royal Observatory.
Location: South Africa

Photo.Title: The Lady and the Devil
Photo.Description: "A Scene in the New Farce of the Lady and the Devil" by Benbow. Satirical print on the relationship between King George IV and his estranged wife Caroline of Brunswick.

Photo.Title: Head and Brains
Photo.Description: Satire on George IV in support of Queen Caroline, his estranged wife. The new king spent much of the lead up to his coronation trying to get rid of her.

Photo.Title: Sir Henry Cole's Rat
Photo.Description:
At 15, Henry Cole, later to find fame as organiser of the Great Exhibition began working with the records of the British government. Shocked at their poor condition he pioneered reform of what became known as the Public Record Office - now The National Archives.
This rat, with a stomach full of chewed document, was used as evidence for the poor condition of the records.

Photo.Title: CO 1069-214-112
Photo.Description:
St. Andrew's College
Location: Grahamstown, South Africa

Photo.Title: CO 1069-214-123
Photo.Description:
The South African Museum
Location: South Africa

Photo.Title: CO 1069-7-10
Photo.Description:
View of the Church of Atebi (or Atebidera or Atsbi).
Location: Atsbi, Abyssinia

Photo.Title: CO 1069-7-16
Photo.Description: Review at Debra Beshan.

Photo.Title: Son of Onnese Obi Osai
Photo.Description:
Inside front cover of the medical and surgical journal of His Majesty's Steam Ship Albert by J O McWilliam, MD, Surgeon. The Albert explored the course of the Niger River from 1841.
"'One of the sons of Onnese Obi Osai chief of Aboh, River Niger', drawn by John Duncan. The illustration appears to have been cut from a published source and pasted inside the journal. Beneath it is a written note 'Ali Hare came on board accompanied by a dozen little boys, who seemed to be nearly coeval [the same age]. These were sons of the Obi."

Photo.Title: CO 1069-214-12
Photo.Description:
Dutch Reformed Church
Location: Cape Town, South Africa

Photo.Title: A case of Scurvy
Photo.Description: Page from the journal of Henry Walsh Mahon showing the effects of scurvy, from his time aboard HM Convict Ship Barrosa.

Photo.Title: Rebecca Riots
Photo.Description:
Edward Crompton Lloyd Hall, high sheriff of Cardiganshire, offers advice to "Rebecca and her daughters".
In 1843 Welsh people rioted against expensive turnpike fees to use the roads, destroying tollgates set up to collect the charges. The name "Rebecca" comes from a biblical reference to in Genesis which suggests her descendants will take command of gates. Some of the rioters also wore women's clothing.

Photo.Title: Log of the Samarang
Photo.Description: Frontispiece of the journal of Henry Walsh Mahon, surgeon aboard HMS Samarang.

Photo.Title: Sea snakes of the Southern Ocean
Photo.Description: Page from the journal of Henry Walsh Mahon, surgeon aboard HMS Samarang. "Although not equipped with poisonous fangs, one of these snakes bit an officer of the HMS Woolf who died within a few hours."

Photo.Title: Long Nosed Monkey
Photo.Description: Page from the journal of Henry Walsh Mahon, surgeon aboard HMS Samarang. "A sketch of a young Symnopithecus Nasalis [Semnopithecus Nasalis] of Borneo. Skin sent to Haslar Museum".

Photo.Title: Cassia Alata
Photo.Description: Page from the journal of Henry Walsh Mahon, surgeon aboard HMS Samarang. Watercolour of the Cassia Alata or Acapuleo of Manila, signed Arthur Adams [delt]. The journal contains notes on the plant's medical properties.

Photo.Title: Such Meetings Are Illegal
Photo.Description: Metropolitan Police poster warning Chartists against gathering in London. In April thousands of Chartists had gathered on Kennington Common to demand democratic reform.

Photo.Title: Stephen Stokes' Master Plan
Photo.Description:
In 1847 explorer Sir John Franklin set out on an expedition to find a Northwest Passage through the Arctic. Years later he still had not returned and the British Admiralty began to make plans to discover his fate. They offered a large reward for information as to the whereabouts of the expedition.
Many people sent in complicated schemes to locate the explorers. This plan by Stephen Stokes suggests suspending a man with a telescope from a series of large kites.

Photo.Title: CO 1069-34-37
Photo.Description: Avenue of Cotton Trees Elmma. (The trees were planted by the Dutch about 50 years - 1850)

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-51
Photo.Description:
Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, the Prime Minister of the Gold Coast, Watches an operator at work on a machine producing metal labels in a factory set up under the suspices of the Industrial Development Corporation of the Gold Coast. Dr. Nkrumah has been Prime Minister since that office was created in 1952.
Location: Gold Coast, Ghana, America, United Kingdom

Photo.Title: Wall to Wall Crystal Palace
Photo.Description: Design for Great Exhibition wallpaper. The 1851 Exhibition held in London's Hyde Park inside the purpose built Crystal Palace received millions of visitors.

Photo.Title: A Grand Day Out
Photo.Description: Ladies ticket to the Great Exhibition at Crystal Palace, then in Hyde Park. The Exhibition opened on May Day 1851.

Photo.Title: CO 1069-111-1
Photo.Description:
Sir Alfred Sharpe (1853-1935) Governor of Nyasaland 1907-1910 Photo Taken from Nyasaland: The Land of The Lake By Frank Debenham,1955
Location: Nyasaland

Photo.Title: Crimea Officers
Photo.Description: "Major [John] Stokes and others." Stokes (seated) was the Chief Engineer of the Anglo-Turkish contingent during the Crimean War.

Photo.Title: Sudden Shower
Photo.Description: "Sudden Shower Over Shin-Ohashi Bridge and Ataker" by 19th century Japanese artist Utagawa Hiroshige.

Photo.Title: Donkey Rail Complaints
Photo.Description: George Hoy's Donkey Challenge to the Eastern Counties Railway Company.

Photo.Title: Houses belonging to the Royal Concubines
Photo.Description: Illustrations of the "Pelew Islands" by T Coghlan, Assistant Surgeon on HMS Sphinx. These included the modern day Mariana Islands as well as Palau.

Photo.Title: Mata'utu Cathedral
Photo.Description: Illustration from the medical and surgical journal of William Fasken, MD, surgeon aboard HMS Fawn. Painting shows the "Queen's House and French Cathedral, Wallis Island" an island group between Fiji and Samoa. The Cathedral still stands today.

Photo.Title: Landing place at Guam
Photo.Description: Illustrations of the "Pelew Islands" by T Coghlan, Assistant Surgeon on HMS Sphinx. These included the modern day Mariana Islands as well as Palau.

Photo.Title: Pioneer Gunboat
Photo.Description:
Page from the medical and surgical journal of A B Messer, Assistant Surgeon aboard HMS Curacoa. Plan of the interior of the gunboat sent from the ship to put down a Maori rebellion in New Zealand.
This assault is sometimes called the Waikato invasion and was the largest conflict between European migrants and the Maori in the mid-19th century New Zealand Wars.

Photo.Title: Skull of a Northern Indian
CO 1069-22-7

New road from Tombel Wharf to Tombel.
Location: Cameroons

Photo.Title: Charting rebellious New Zealand
Photo.Description:
Chart from the medical and surgical journal of A B Messer, Assistant Surgeon aboard HMS Curacoa. The map shows the area of New Zealand in which his brigade was employed in putting down a Maori uprising in the summer of 1863.
This assault is sometimes called the Waikato invasion and was the largest conflict between European migrants and the Maori in the mid-19th century New Zealand Wars.

The watercolour illustration shows four views of Christopher Walters' 'Retinitis Syphilitica' [the retina of someone with syphilis] at different stages of treatment, as viewed through an ophthalmoscope.

Photo.Title: Paying the last turnpike toll
Photo.Description:
"W. Ambrose Esq. paying last toll Burwell Nest Toll Bar, Cambs." Photo by Frederick Gillson's "Sunnyside Studios" in Burwell.
In decline from the 1870s this photograph purports to show the last payment for travelling along a turnpike (toll) road. Turnpikes were administered by trusts, formed to maintain the roads. At its peak in the 1830s, this unpopular system was rendered largely unprofitable by the arrival of the railways. Local councils took over responsibility for roads by 1890.

Photo.Title: Rolls in a Basket
Photo.Description:
"Photograph of the late C.S. Rolls and Hon. Mrs. Assheton Harbord in basket of balloon", by Horace Hall.
Charles Stewart Rolls became interested in flying after he had already founded Rolls-Royce in 1904. Though the badge is indistinct this balloon may be his 'Midget'. In 1910 Rolls was killed in an aeroplane accident.
Mrs. Assheton Harbord owned her own balloon (Nebia) and was a dedicated aeronaut, crossing the Channel a number of times.

Photo.Title: Sophie Gaudier Brzeska
Photo.Description: Photograph of Sophie Gaudier Brzeska, writer and muse to the sculptor and Vorticist painter Henri Gaudier-Brzeska. Born in Poland. Sophie ended her life in a British asylum in 1925 after Henri's death in the First World War. This photograph was among her effects.

Photo.Title: Cross Channel Pioneer
Photo.Description:
"'Photograph of Mons Pierre Prier in the cross channel Bleriot monoplane" taken by John Edward Fletcher.
Prier was the first person to fly non stop from Paris to London, completing the feat in a little under five hours in April 1911. He is shown seated in the plane he used.

Photo.Title: House proud?
Photo.Description: Photograph taken to demonstrate some of the worst housing conditions in British Antigua. The island was in the process of carrying out slum clearance. The file reads "I believe I am correct in stating that, nowhere in the British West Indies, are the working people more wretchedly housed and more detached from the land than in Antigua."

Photo.Title: Hiram Maxim's Glider
Photo.Description:
The Anglo-American inventor of the machine gun, Sir Hiram Maxim experimented unsuccessfully with powered flight during much of the 1890s.
In 1911 he established a company to develop military aircraft with Louis Blériot, the first man to fly across the English Channel and engineer Claude Grahame White, one of Britain's first qualified pilots.

Photo.Title: Corporal Jack Harris's Pierrot Troupe
Photo.Description:
Prisoners of War interned at Rennbahn in Munster, North Germany, a converted racecourse. Amateur theatricals offered a distraction from gruelling conditions at the camp. The elaborate set here formed part of the "Rennbahn Empire" where prisoners regularly put on shows.
Jack Harris served in the Rifle Brigade and was a music hall comedian before the war.

Photo.Description:
The Main Guard.

Photo.Title: CO 1069-25-32
Photo.Description:
Gambia Cenotaph. The two minutes silence (1922)
Location: Gambia

Photo.Title: CO 1069-25-31
Photo.Description:
Gambia Cenotaph. (To Gambia company, West African Frontier Force). Unveiling Ceremony, 11 November, 1922.
Location: Gambia

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-13
Photo.Description:
My personal staff. In the centre my dear, old faithful Zuwa with my two Somali boys Ahamed and Gulaid on each side; both these two boys served me well and truly.
Location: Nyasaland, Somaliland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-12
Photo.Description:
Shows the gun in action.
Location: Nyasaland, Somaliland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-11
Photo.Description:
Zarebas built whilst on patrol. It will be noticed that the zareba in picture No.50 mounts a 12pdr. gun. This was manned by "A" Somali Camel Company. The origin of the gun is lost in the depths of mystery.
Location: Nyasaland, Somaliland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-10
Photo.Description:
Company Somali section(Vet. assistants; saddlers; fitters; and pony orderlies) on the march.
Location: Nyasaland, Somaliland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-9
Photo.Description:
Self and Lieut.K.G.Fernie, 8th Royal Hussars, at the end of a many weeks patrol. The dog is mine.
Location: Nyasaland, Somaliland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-8
Photo.Description:
Company machine-gun section in action.
Location: Nyasaland, Somaliland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-7
Photo.Description:
Company on patrol.
Location: Nyasaland, Somaliland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-6
Photo.Description:
From left to right, Sgt. Kandula, the incomparable C.S.M.Saidi and Sgt Muli commanding the M.G.Troop.
Location: Nyasaland, Somaliland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-5
Photo.Description:
Typical Somali country: sand, stones and thornbush. Approaching an enemy fort erected on the only waterhole for miles, used by the local robber sultan to squeeze his ten per cent from all tribes watering at the hole. Actually this fort was on the British-Italian frontier, and the Ities objected strongly to our operations.
Location: Nyasaland, Somaliland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-4
Photo.Description:
Self with my two junior "boys" Saidi and Amaydi. They both came with me from Songea but had to leave me, much to my regret, when I was sent to Somaliland.
Location: Zomba, Songea, Nyasaland, Somaliland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-13-3
Photo.Description:
A group photograph, taken at Zomba? during an inspection by the Inspector General of the King's African Rifles, of the Officers and British NCOS. during the summer of, I think, 1922. The IG's name, again I think, was Hawthorne, his staff-officer Edwards, the CO. of the battalion Philips; the chap in plain-clothes in the back rank is the doctor. Looking at the picture I am theleft hand chap sitting on my bottom in the font frow, a very minor person. I can remember the names of some of the others but it is too long to detail them with hats on.
Location: Zomba, Nyasaland

Photo.Title: CO 1069-42-89
Photo.Description:
Map of the Gold Coast Railway. Showing Feeder Road and the Principal Agriculture and Mineral Areas.
Location: Gold Coast, Takoradi, Accra

Photo.Title: How girls become "dope fiends"!!
Photo.Description: Trade advert in The Bioscope to encourage cinema owners to book the film 'Cocaine' directed by Graham Cutts. The Home Office conducted an aggressive campaign to attempt to ensure the film was not widely screened.

Photo.Title: Film poster for Maisie's Marriage (1923)
Photo.Description: Based (very loosely!) on Marie Stopes' best selling book "Married Love" and starring leading British silent star Lillian Hall-Davis, Maisie's Marriage was subject to an aggressive censorship campaign by the Home Office and British Board of Film Censors.

Photo.Title: Bloomsbury Metrosexuals
Photo.Description:
Photograph used in evidence for a prosecution for "keeping a disorderly house" in a flat in London's fashionable Fitzroy Square, previously home to members of the Bloomsbury Group such as Virginia Woolf. Robert Britt (second left) a dancer at the London Empire theatre was the flat's owner.
Those pictured were all arrested and tried after police staked out the flat and raided it. For little more than attending house parties at the flat, a number of the men pictured were sentenced to more than six months in prison. Britt was sentenced to 15 months hard labour.

Photo.Title: The Future is Now
Photo.Description:
A British made Cierva Autogiro flies over Manhattan Island. The brainchild of Spanish aeronautical engineer Juan de la Cierva, the autogyro was developed in the early 1920s.
The National Archives' file relates to proposals within the Great Western Railway company to build what would now be called helipads at railway stations.

Photo.Title: Why help foreigners?
Photo.Description:
Nazi propaganda poster for use in schools as part of their "parole die woche" (slogan of the week) programme.
This highly anti-semitic poster claims that the British working class believe that resources should be mobilised to help underprivileged British people ahead of "Jewish criminals chucked out of Germany". The poster criticises the Archbishop of Canterbury, Cosmo Lang, for his defence of Jewish immigrants to the UK.

Photo.Title: Awaiting Rescue
Photo.Description: Aerial photograph of lifeboat from the SS City of Benares. The passenger liner was carrying children being evacuated from Britain to Canada when it was sunk in a U-Boat attack on the convoy in which it was travelling. Only 13 of the 90 children on board survived and government evacuation of children to the Dominions such as Canada, New Zealand and Australia (the CORB scheme) immediately ceased.

Photo.Title: Back to the wall
Photo.Description: "Back to the wall" by Leslie Illingworth. Churchill (as John Bull) guards a wall also being defended by British Empire forces.

Photo.Title: Your Ration Book
Photo.Description: Sample Child's Ration Book. Throughout the 1940s (and for nine years after the end of the war) every man woman and child in Britain owned ration books of coupons for food and clothing. The Ministry of Food's carefully formulated diet is generally believed to have improved the nation's health.

Photo.Title: Evacuees to New Zealand
Photo.Description: Children's Overseas Reception Board (CORB) group bound for New Zealand. At the outbreak of World War Two, thousands of British children were sent to the Dominions (Canada, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa) before attacks on shipping prematurely ended the scheme.

Photo.Title: Just George
Photo.Description: Photographs of Eric Blair (George Orwell) from his Metropolitan Police file

Photo.Title: Atomic Agent
Photo.Description: Police photograph of Physicist Klaus Fuchs. In 1933 Fuchs fled Germany for Britain. During the War he worked on the Manhattan Project in the United States to build the Atomic Bomb and later worked on British nuclear projects. In 1950 he admitted spying for the Russians since 1942 and passing on details of British and American nuclear technology.

Photo.Title: "Pam"
Photo.Description:
MI5 staff member pictured on beach. This ordinary looking snapshot was taken and planted as part of a complex WWII intelligence plan known as Operation Mincemeat.
The intention was that this photograph would make other documents secreted with it seem more authentic. These documents, passed on to German agents after they were found on a body washed up on the coast of Spain (planted by British intelligence) suggested that the Allies were not planning an invasion of southern Europe via Sicily. This led to a weakening of German defence of Sicily which assisted the eventual Allied attack.

Photo.Title: Ian Fleming's Operation Ruthless
Photo.Description:
During the Second World War Ian Fleming served as a Commander in the Royal Navy as assistant to the Director of Naval Intelligence, Rear Admiral John Godfrey. This document outlines Fleming's plan to capture German Engima codebooks which he dubbed 'Operation Ruthless'.
Fleming's name for the operation and his description of the man needed as a "tough batchelor" can't help but recall his later creation of James Bond. The document, prepared after the war as a summary of the activities of Naval Intelligence, suggests Fleming volunteered himself for the mission.

Photo.Title: Ian Fleming's Operation Ruthless - Page 2
Photo.Description:
During the Second World War Ian Fleming served as a Commander in the Royal Navy as assistant to the Director of Naval Intelligence, Rear Admiral John Godfrey. This document outlines Fleming's plan to capture German Engima codebooks which he dubbed 'Operation Ruthless'.
Fleming's name for the operation and his description of the man needed as a "tough batchelor" can't help but recall his later creation of James Bond. This part of the document, prepared after the war as a summary of the activities of Naval Intelligence, highlights the interest of codebreaker and mathematical genius Alan Turing in Fleming's plan.

Photo.Title: O Christmas Tree
Photo.Description:
Lighting up of the first Norwegian Christmas tree in Trafalgar Square.
A tree has been given every year to Britain since 1947 by Norway in gratitude for Britain's support for the country during the Second World War. Norway's Government-in-Exile was based in Kensington while the country was under German occupation.
You can find out more about the trees on the <a href="http://www.london.gov.uk/trafalgarsquare/events/xmas.jsp" rel="nofollow">GLA website.

Photo.Title: The last grain race
Photo.Description: In the early 20th century sailing ships would compete to be the first to bring a grain cargo from Australia to the UK. Built in 1911 S.V. Passat was the winner of the final race in 1949/50, reaching Penarth, Wales in four months. Its cargo of wheat was destined for the mills of Methodist mill owner and film magnate J. Arthur Rank.

Photo.Title: Animal Farm artwork
Photo.Description:
Preliminary drawing for design of Animal Farm strip cartoon.
In 1950 the Foreign Office commissioned a strip cartoon version of Animal Farm from the cartoonist Norman Pett and his writing partner Donald Freeman. Various embassies then encouraged overseas newspapers to publish the anti-communist strip. It was translated into a number of languages and also turned into a slide show for public performance.
<a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/nationalarchives/4245149964/in/photostream/">The first installment is also on Flickr

Photo.Title: Animal Farm strip cartoon

Foreign Office copy of first installment of Norman Pett's Animal Farm comic strip.
In 1950 the Foreign Office commissioned a strip cartoon version of Animal Farm from the cartoonist Norman Pett and his writing partner Donald Freeman. Various embassies then encouraged overseas newspapers to publish the anti-communist strip. It was translated into a number of languages and also turned into a slide show for public performance.

Photo.Title: Aerial Photography before Google
Photo.Description: Aerial photograph of Aberdeen from the records of Naval Intelligence (UK Beach Intelligence) on a survey of Girdle Ness to Rattray Head.

Photo.Title: Fifties Melbourne
Photo.Description: Aerial photograph of Melbourne produced by the Australian News and Information Bureau and supplied to the British Central Office of Information.

Photo.Title: CO 1069-3-265
Photo.Description:
Visit of the Secretary of State to Barotseland. January 1957.
Location: Barotseland, N. Rhodesia, Zambia

Photo.Title: CO 1069-53-78
Photo.Description:
St. George's Castle at Elmina on the shores of the Gold Coast. Elmina Castle, as it is usually called, and other forts were built along the coast by the Portuguese after their first settlement in 1482.
Location: Gold Coast, Elmina, Ghana, United Kingdom

Photo.Title: CO 1069-53-76
Photo.Description:
The Gold Coast Legislative Assembly in session, presided over by the Speaker.
Location: Gold Coast, Ghana

Photo.Title: CO 1069-53-74
Photo.Description:
A voter receives a ballot paper from a polling assistant at Kungungu Polling Station in the Northern Territories.
Location: Gold Coast, Kungungu, Ghana

Photo.Title: CO 1069-53-72
Photo.Description:
A British research worker, examines a cage of Simulium flies, which is attached to a tree overhanging the Black Volta river. These flies, carriers of onchocerciasis, a disease which leads to blindness, are bred for research purposes.
Location: Gold Coast, Ghana, United Kingdom

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-57
Photo.Description:
Station Road, Accra, looking north towards Tsawan. Accra, the capital town of the Gold Coast, is the home of 150,000 people. The town is developing fast.
Location: Gold Coast, Accra, Tsawan, Ghana

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-55
Photo.Description:
A meeting of the Management Comittee of the Kumasi Co-operative Union in Ashanti. Kumasi is the centre of a cocoa growing area. The Co-operative Union has some 60 rural societies and a membership of about 6,000 farmers.
Location: Gold Coast, Kumasi, Ashanti, Ghana

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-53
Photo.Description:
The Governor (second from left) watches fourth-year boys operating lathes at the Trade Training Centre in Tamale, Northern territories. This Centre provides four-year courses for boys leaving middle schools, and evening classes for those who go from the middle schools, and evening classes for those who go from the middle schools into industry.
Location: Gold Coast, Tamale, Takoradi, Kumasi, Ashanti, Ghana, United Kingdom

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-47
Photo.Description:
The new housing estate which has recently been completed at South Sunstresu, near Kumasi in Ashanti. The local authority runs a bus service between South Sunstresu and Kumasi.
Location: Gold Coast, South Sunstresu, Kumasi, Ashanti, Ghana, United Kingdom

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-45
Photo.Description:
A housewife in Yendi pours water into a meal (left) and the children play.
Location: Gold Coast, Yendi, Kumasi, Ghana

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-43
Photo.Description:
A bus stop outside the new extension to the General Post Office in Accra. The General Post Office is one of the many new modern buildings which to-day grace the streets of Accra, the capital of the Gold Coast.
Location: Gold Coast, Accra, Ghana, United Kingdom

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-41
Photo.Description:
The new bridge across the Volta River at Adoni, which together with a new trunk road, part of which can be seen in the background, will link the new part of Tena with Togoland.
Location: Gold Coast, Adoni, Tena, Takoradi, Ghana, Togoland, United Kingdom

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-39
Photo.Description:
A weaver plies his craft at Flyboyiri. The practice of arts and crafts is encouraged throughout the Gold Coast by mass education teams, who also teach reading and writing.
Location: Gold Coast, Flyboyiri, Ghana, United Kingdom

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-37
Photo.Description:
Gold miners at work in the Tarkwa Gold Mine This drilling machine crew are working 1,800 feet below the ground.
Location: Gold Coast, Ghana, Britain

Photo.Title: CO 1069-46-35
Photo.Description:

Photo.Title: Militant School Children
Photo.Description:
Letter from Conservative Prime Minister Edward Heath's Private Secretary Robert Armstrong to the Department of Education, then headed by Margaret Thatcher.
Thatcher and Heath never got on and it is notable that this communication (in which Armstrong refers to the 1968 Paris Riots) is between their respective civil servants and not in any way personal.
The file also contains an example of left wing material intended for London schools.
